sen.j: 菅谷館（城）（すがややかた（じょう））とは、武蔵国男衾郡（鎌倉時代当時、現在の埼玉県比企郡嵐山町）にあった城である。
sen.e: Sugaya-yakata Castle was located in Obusuma-gun, Musashi Province (in the Kamakura period, present Ranzan-machi, Hiki-gun, Saitama Prefecture).
Sugaya-yakata Castle was located in Obusuma-gun, Musashi Province (in the Kamakura period, present Ranzan-machi, Hiki-gun, Saitama Prefecture).
Sugaya-yakata Castle was located in Obusuma-gun, Musashi Province (in the Kamakura period, present Ranzan-machi, Hiki-gun, Saitama Prefecture).

sen.j: 昭和48年（1973年）、国の史跡に指定された。
sen.e: It was designated as a national historic site in 1973.
It was designated as a national historic site in 1973.
It was designated as a national historic site in 1973.

sen.j: 館跡には埼玉県立嵐山史跡の博物館が設けられている。
sen.e: Saitama Prefectural Historical Museum of Ranzan has been built at the former castel site.
Saitama Prefectural Historical Museum of Ranzan was built at the former castle site.
Saitama Prefectural Historical Museum of Ranzan was built at the former castle site.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の有力御家人として知られる畠山重忠の館跡である。
sen.e: It was the residence of Shigetada HATAKEYAMA known as a dominant gokenin (an immediate vasal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods） in the Kamakura bakufu.
It was the residence of Shigetada HATAKEYAMA known as a dominant gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura, Muromachi and Edo periods） in the Kamakura bakufu.

It is the remains of the residence of Shigetada HATAKEYAMA, known as a dominant gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura, Muromachi and Edo periods） in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 畠山氏は、重忠の父畠山重能の代から大里郡畠山荘の荘司であり、重忠も当初は同荘内に館を置いていた。
sen.e: The head of the HATAKEYAMA clan was the shoji (sho-en estate keeper) of Hatakeyamano-sho Estate in Osato-gun since the the generation of Shigeyoshi HATAKEYAMA, Shigetada's father, and Shigetada placed his residence there as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The head of the HATAKEYAMA clan was the shoji (sho-en estate keeper) of Hatakeyamano-sho Estate in Osato-gun since Shigetada's father's (Shigeyoshi HATAKEYAMA) generation, and Shigetada placed his residence there as well.

The HATAKEYAMA clan was the shoji (sho-en estate keeper) of Hatakeyamano-sho Estate in Osato-gun since Shigetada's father, Shigeyoshi HATAKEYAMA, and Shigetada initially placed his residence within the estate.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。アポストロフィを修正

sen.j: しかし、やがて鎌倉街道の要衝にあたる菅谷の地に移って館を構えたのが始まりである。
sen.e: However, later, he moved his residence to Sugaya, a stratigic spot along Kamakura-kaido Road, which was the origin of this castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, he later moved his residence to Sugaya, a stratigic spot along Kamakura-kaido Road, which was the origin of this castle.
However, he later moved to Sugaya, a strategic spot along the Kamakura-kaido Road, which is the origin of this castle.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 元久2年（1205年）、畠山重忠が武蔵国二俣川（現・神奈川県横浜市旭区 (横浜市)）で戦死した。
sen.e: In 1205, Shigetada HATAKEYAMA died in a battle at Futamatagawa in Musashi Province (present Asahi Ward, Yokohama City, Knagawa Rpefecture (Yokohama City).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1205, Shigetada HATAKEYAMA died in a battle at Futamatagawa in Musashi Province (present Asahi Ward, Yokohama City, Kanagawa prefecture).
In 1205, Shigetada HATAKEYAMA died in a battle at Futamatagawa in Musashi Province (present Asahi Ward, Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture).

sen.j: のちは畠山の名跡を継いだ足利義純の子孫に伝えられたというが、15世紀後半に至るまでの詳細は不明である。
sen.e: After that, it is said that the castle was inherited by the descendents of Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA who inherited the family name of HATAKEYAMA, but the details are unknown until the later years of the 15-th century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After that, it is said that the castle was inherited by the descendents of Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA who inherited the family name of HATAKEYAMA, but the details are unknown until the later years of the 15th century.

Subsequently, it is said that the castle was inherited by the descendents of Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA who inherited the family name of HATAKEYAMA, but the details until the later years of the 15th century are unknown.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 長享2年（1488年）頃に山内上杉家が扇谷上杉家方の川越城に対するおさえとして、菅谷の旧城を再興した。
sen.e: In around 1488, the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family reconstructed the old castle at Sugaya against Kawagoe-jo Castle of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family
In around 1488, the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family reconstructed the old castle at Sugaya against Kawagoe-jo Castle of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
In around 1488, the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family reconstructed the old castle at Sugaya to compete against Kawagoe-jo Castle of the Ogigayatsu-Uesugi family.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 以後、16世紀前半まで山内上杉家の拠点として使われる。
sen.e: From then to the first half of 16-th century, it was used by the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family as its strategic site.
From that point to the first half of 16th century, it was used by the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family as its strategic site.
From that point onwards to the first half of 16th century, it was used by the Yamanouchi-Uesugi family as its base.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: また、長享2年には、この城の近くで須賀谷原の戦い（すがやはらがっせん）が起こっている。
sen.e: In 1488, the battle of Sugayahara broke out around this castle.
In 1488, the battle of Sugayahara broke out around this castle.
In 1488, the battle of Sugayahara broke out around this castle.

sen.j: その後は、天文 (元号)15年（1546年）の河越夜戦以降にこの地域に進出した後北条氏によって戦国末期まで使われたとする説と、後北条氏進出以前に廃絶したとする説がある。
sen.e: Concerning the situation of the castle after that, there exit the following two opinions: According to one of them, the Gohojo clan, which came to and controlled this area after the night battle of Kawagoe, used it until around the end of the Sengoku period (period of warring states), and the other says that the castle was abolished before the Gohojo clan came to control the area.

There are two opinions on the situation of the castle after that: the Gohojo clan, which came to and controlled this area after the night battle of Kawagoe, used it until around the end of the Sengoku period (period of warring states); and another account has the castle abolished before the Gohojo clan came to control the area.

There are two theories regarding the fate of the castle after the battle: one that the Gohojo clan, who came and controlled this area after the night battle of Kawagoe in 1546, used it until around the end of the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the other that the castle was abandoned before the Gohojo clan came to control the area.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 発掘調査の結果からは後北条氏時代の遺物が出土しておらず、後北条氏以前に廃城となった可能性が高い。
sen.e: According to exavation results of the site, relics in the Gohojo clan era are found and it is highly possible that the castle was ablished before the Gohojo clan took the site.
According to excavation results of the site, relics in the Gohojo clan era are found and it is highly possible that the castle was ablished before the Gohojo clan took the site.
According to excavation results of the site, remains from the Gohojo clan era have not been found and it is highly possible that the castle was abandoned before the Gohojo clan came.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 館跡は都幾川と槻川の合流点北側の低台地にある平城で、館（城）の付近を鎌倉街道上道が通っていた。
sen.e: The former castle site is located on the low plateau on the north side of the place where the Tsuki-gawa River and the Tsuki-gawa River meet, the castle was a hira-jiro (a castle built on flat land), and the Kmitsumichi Kamakura-kaido Road (one of the three Kamakura-kaido Roads) ran near to the residence (castel).

The former castle site is located on a low plateau on the north side of the confluence of the Tsuki-gawa and Tsuki-gawa Rivers meet. The castle was a hira-jiro (a castle built on flat land), and the Kimitsumichi Kamakura-kaido Road (one of the three Kamakura-kaido Roads) ran near to the residence (castle).

The former residence was a hira-jiro (a castle built on flat land) located on a low plateau on the north side of where the Toki-gawa and Tsuki-gawa Rivers meet and the Kamitsumichi Kamakura-kaido Road (one of the three Kamakura-kaido Roads) ran near the residence (castle).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 館跡中央のやや南寄りに平面長方形の本丸があり、その北側に二の丸、三の丸などを配置してある。
sen.e: A horizontally rectangular Honmaru (the keep of a castle) was placed slightly to the south of the center of the castel site, with the ninomaru (second bailey) and the sannomaru (outer part of the castle) to the north of it, and each kuruwa-area (a space reserved for various purposes) was protected with mounds and walls.

A horizontally rectangular Honmaru (the keep of the castle) was placed slightly to the south of the center of the castle site, with the ninomaru (second bailey) and the sannomaru (outer part of the castle) to the north of it. Each kuruwa-area (a space reserved for various purposes) was protected with mounds and walls.

A horizontally rectangular honmaru (the keep of the castle) was placed slightly to the south of the center of the castle site, with the ninomaru (second bailey) and the sannomaru (outer part of the castle) to the north of it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: それぞれの曲輪を土塁と堀で防備している。
sen.e: Each kuruwa-area (a space reserved for various purposes) was protected with mounds and moats.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 「堀」の訳を、moat にしました。

sen.j: 土塁の遺存状況は良好であり、曲輪の配置や土塁の構築法には近世的な平城の特徴をうかがうことができる。
sen.e: The relics of the mounds remain in a good state, and features of hira-jiro castles in the modern times can be seen in the layout of the kuruwa and in the architecture of the mounds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The relics of the mounds remain in a good state, and the features of hira-jiro castles in the modern times can be seen in the layout of the kuruwa and in the architecture of the mounds.

The remains of the mounds are in good condition and the features of hira-jiro castles in the modern times can be seen in the layout of the kuruwa (surrounding walls) and in the architecture of the mounds.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 本丸は単郭式の城館の面影をよくとどめており、鎌倉時代における菅谷館の中心部分と考えられる。
sen.e: The honmaru keeps an image of a castle using the tankaku-shiki structure (a structure provided with only one reserved space) well and is considered to have been the central part of Sugaya-yakata Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The honmaru keeps an image of a castle using the tankaku-shiki structure (a structure provided with only one reserved space) well and is considered to have been the central part of Sugaya-yakata Castle.

The honmaru (main enclosure) retains the vestiges of a tankaku (single enclosure) style castle residence and is considered to have been the central part of Sugaya residence during the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 中世館跡の遺構例としては稀少な遺跡であり、保存度もきわめて良好である。
sen.e: It is one of the rare sites where relics of castles in the medieval period remain, being kept in a quite goot state as wel.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is one of the rare sites where relics of castles in the medieval period remain, being well preserved.
It is a rare site of a castle residence from the medieval period and is well preserved.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 1973年（昭和48年）5月26日、「菅谷館跡」（すがややかたあと）として国の史跡に指定された。
sen.e: It was designated for a national historical site on May 26, 1973 as "The former site of Sugaya-yakata Castle."
It was designated a national historical site on May 26, 1973 as The former site of Sugaya-yakata Castle.
It was designated a national historical site on May 26, 1973 as The former site of Sugaya-yakata Castle.

sen.j: ただし、当時指定管理方針が確定していなかったため東側の堀跡の一部が未指定に終わった。
sen.e: However, part of the former wall site on the eastern side remains undesignated, because how to manage the designated area was not determined at that time.
However, part of the former wall site on the eastern side remains undesignated, because the management of the designated area was not determined at that time.
However, part of the former moat site on the eastern side remains undesignated because guidelines for designated area were not determined at that time.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 1976年（昭和51年）12月、1973年の指定において未指定とされていた東側堀跡の一部を埼玉県が史跡用地として管理することが決まったので、当該部分の追加指定がなされた。
sen.e: In December of 1976, it was decided that Saitama Prefecture should manage the part of the former wall site that remained undesignated in the designation in 1973, and that part was newly included in the national historical site.

In December of 1976, it was decided that Saitama Prefecture should manage the part of the former wall site that remained undesignated in the 1973 designation. That part was newly included in the national historical site.

In December of 1976, it was decided that Saitama Prefecture should manage the part of the eastern side moat site that remained undesignated in the 1973 designation, and that part was designated and added to the national historical site.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 2008年（平成20年）3月28日、菅谷館跡に松山城 (武蔵国)跡、杉山城跡、小倉城 (武蔵国)跡が加わり「比企城館跡群」としてあらためて国の史跡として広域指定された。
sen.e: On March 28, 2008, Hiki-jo Castle Ruins was newly designated as a historical site covering a wide area, adding the former Matsuyama-jo Castle (in Musashi Province) site, the former Sugiyama-jo Castle site and the Ogura-jo Castle (in Musashi Province) site to the former Sugaya-yakata Castle site.

On March 28, 2008, Hiki-jo Castle Ruins was newly designated as a historical site covering a wide area, including the former Matsuyama-jo Castle (in Musashi Province) site, the former Sugiyama-jo Castle site and the Ogura-jo Castle (in Musashi Province) site to the former Sugaya-yakata Castle site.

On March 28, 2008, a national historical site covering a wide area was newly designated as the 'Hiki-jo Castle Ruins,' comprised of the former Sugaya-yakata Castle site in addition to the former Matsuyama-jo Castle (Musashi Province) the Sugiyama-jo Castle and the Ogura-jo Castle (Musashi Province).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 埼玉県比企郡嵐山町大字菅谷
sen.e: Oaza Sugaya, Ranzan Town, Hiki County, Saitama Prefecture
Oaza Sugaya, Ranzan Town, Hiki County, Saitama Prefecture
Oaza Sugaya, Ranzan-machi, Hiki-gun, Saitama Prefecture
sen.cmt: 住所の表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 東武東上本線武蔵嵐山駅西口から徒歩約13分
sen.e: Approx. 13 mintutes on foot from the west exit of Musashi-Ranzan Station on the Tobu Tojo Main Line.
Approximately 13 mintutes on foot from the west exit of the Musashi-Ranzan Station on the Tobu Tojo Main Line.
Approximately 13 minutes on foot from the west exit of the Musashi-Ranzan Station on the Tobu Tojo Main Line.

sen.j: 関越自動車道東松山インターチェンジから車で約10分
sen.e: Approx. 10 mintutes by car from the Higashi-Matsuyama interchange on Kanetsu Expressway
Approximately 10 mintutes by car from the Higashi-Matsuyama interchange on Kanetsu Expressway.
Approximately 10 minutes by car from the Higashi-Matsuyama interchange on the Kanetsu Expressway.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 関越自動車道嵐山小川インターチェンジから車で約10分
sen.e: Approx. 10 mintutes by car from the Ranzan-Ogawa interchange on Kanetsu Expressway
Approximately 10 mintutes by car from the Ranzan-Ogawa interchange on Kanetsu Expressway.
Approximately 10 minutes by car from the Ranzan-Ogawa interchange on the Kanetsu Expressway.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。
